'''Feminist Hulk''' ('''@feministhulk''') is a parody [[Twitter]] account written from the perspective of a [[feminism|feminist]] incarnation of the [[Hulk (comics)|Hulk]], a [[Marvel Comics]] superhero with boundless rage and strength but a limited vocabulary. Feminist Hulk incorporates [[feminist theory]] into tweets, notably threatening to smash the [[patriarchy]] and [[gender binary]]. Blogger Christopher Shea observed that part of the humor "comes from hearing feminist theory spouted by such a [[hypermasculinity|hypermasculine]] figure."<ref name="Shea"/>
==Overview== The Feminist Hulk Twitter profile reads "HULK SAYS FUCK PATRIARCHY. HULK SMASH GENDER BINARY."<ref name="NPR"/> The Twitter [[Avatar (computing)|avatar]] for Feminist Hulk is an image of the Marvel Comics superhero holding a copy of philosopher and gender theorist [[Judith Butler]]'s book ''[[Gender Trouble]]''.<ref name="Salon"/> Feminist Hulk tweets in [[all caps]], but makes an exception for feminist author [[bell hooks]], tweeting "HULK MAKE CAPITALIZATION EXCEPTION FOR bell hooks. HULK LOVE HER ESSAY ON [[Madonna (entertainer)|MADONNA]] AND RACIST [[Cultural appropriation|APPROPRIATION]]".<ref name="Salon"/>
==History== Feminist Hulk started tweeting on May 11, 2010, quickly followed by the online magazine ''[[Salon (website)|Salon]]''.<ref name="Salon">{{cite news|last=Traister|first=Rebecca|title=FEMINIST HULK MAKE TWITTER FUN!|url=http://www.salon.com/2010/05/18/feminist_hulk/|newspaper=Salon|date=May 18, 2010}}</ref> By June 2010, the account had gained over 15,000 followers<ref name="Shea">{{cite web|last=Shea|first=Christopher|title=FEMINIST HULK SMASH SEXISM|url=http://www.boston.com/bostonglobe/ideas/brainiac/2010/06/whats_big_green.html|website=Brainiac|publisher=Boston.com|date=June 15, 2010}}</ref> and had been interviewed on ''[[Ms. (magazine)|Ms.]]'' magazine<ref>{{cite news|last=Bilger|first=Audrey|title=FEMINIST HULK SMASH EXCLUSIVE INTERVIEW WITH MS.!|url=http://msmagazine.com/blog/2010/06/07/feminist-hulk-smash-exclusive-interview-with-ms/|newspaper=Ms.|date=June 7, 2010}}</ref> and Feministing blogs.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Feministing Five: Feminist Hulk|url=http://feministing.com/2011/07/09/the-feministing-five-feminist-hulk/|newspaper=Feministing|date=July 9, 2011|first=Chloe|last=Angyal}}</ref>
By 2011, Feminist Hulk garnered over 40,000 followers and was included in [[Amanda Palmer]]'s "Most Amusing Tweets of the Year" song.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bilger|first=Audrey|title=FEMINIST HULK MEET MS. MAGAZINE: THE SEQUEL|url=http://msmagazine.com/blog/2011/06/20/feminist-hulk-meet-ms-magazine-the-sequel/|newspaper=Ms.|date=June 20, 2011}}</ref> In another interview with ''Ms.'' in August 2011, the writer of the Feminist Hulk revealed her identity as [[University of Iowa]] Ph.D candidate Jessica Lawson. She described herself as a "[[White people|white]], [[vegan]], [[queer]], [[The Woman-Identified Woman|woman-identified female]]."<ref name="Ms3">{{cite news|last=Bilger|first=Audrey|title=Who’s Behind the Mask of Feminist Hulk? Only the Ms. Blog Knows!|url=http://msmagazine.com/blog/2011/08/22/whos-behind-the-mask-of-feminist-hulk-only-the-ms-blog-knows/|newspaper=Ms.|date=August 22, 2011}}</ref> In the interview, she described the Feminist Hulk as more a place where people can test their ideas than a translator for theory, saying "If that just makes Hulk the green doorman for an internet speakeasy of feminist brain-nuzzling, so be it!"<ref name="Ms3"/> Lawson incorporates her own life experiences into Feminist Hulk, tweeting about motherhood, [[veganism|vegan]] baking, and her love for [[kale]].<ref name="NPR"/>
By 2013, Feminist Hulk had 74,000 followers on Twitter.<ref name="Huffpo"/>
===WIC/Formula Resource Project=== In the wake of the [[United States federal government shutdown of 2013]], insufficient funding disrupted some [[WIC]] food and nutrition programs. Lawson, herself a single mother, set up the website feministhulk.net, using the site as a directory for women who need to find resources during the shutdown and for people who would like to make donations.<ref name="Huffpo">{{cite news|last=Belkin|first=Lisa|title=Where To Find Formula And Baby Food During A WIC Shutdown|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/10/07/where-to-find-formula-baby-food-wic-shutdown_n_4059616.html|newspaper=Huffington Post|date=October 7, 2013}}</ref> The site includes links to lists of [[food bank]]s and a state-by-state guide to resources for [[infant formula]] and updates on the status of WIC.<ref name="NPR">{{cite news|last=Woodsome|first=Kate|title=Feminist Hulk Smash Shutdown, Rescue Women On Food Aid!|url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/thesalt/2013/10/12/232306911/feminist-hulk-smash-shutdown-rescue-women-on-food-aid|newspaper=NPR|date=October 12, 2013}}</ref>
==See also== *[[She-Hulk]]
==References== {{Reflist|33em}}

In [[abstract algebra]], the '''[[fundamental theorem]] on homomorphisms''', also known as the '''fundamental homomorphism theorem''', relates the structure of two objects between which a [[homomorphism]] is given, and of the [[Kernel (algebra)|kernel]] and image of the homomorphism.
The homomorphism theorem is used to prove the [[isomorphism theorem]]s.
== Group theoretic version ==
Given two [[group (mathematics)|group]]s ''G'' and ''H'' and a [[group homomorphism]] ''f'' : ''G''→''H'', let ''K'' be a [[normal subgroup]] in ''G'' and φ the natural [[surjective]] homomorphism ''G''→''G''/''K'' (where ''G''/''K'' is a [[quotient group]]). If ''K'' is a subset of [[kernel (algebra)|ker]](''f'') then there exists a unique homomorphism ''h'':''G''/''K''→''H'' such that ''f'' = ''h'' φ.
In other words, the natural projection φ is [[Universal property|universal]] among homomorphisms on ''G'' that map ''K'' to the identity element.
The situation is described by the following [[commutative diagram]]:
[[File:Fundamental Homomorphism Theorem.svg]]
By setting ''K'' = ker(''f'') we immediately get the [[first isomorphism theorem]].
== Other versions == Similar theorems are valid for [[monoid]]s, [[vector space]]s, [[module (mathematics)|modules]], and [[ring (mathematics)|rings]].
==See also== * [[Quotient category]]
